researchPapers.title: Environmental determinants of shark attacks: a review of published data
keyFindings: Water temperature is a significant predictor of shark presence in temperate coastal zones
Seasonal patterns show increased activity during warmer months (Nov-Feb in Southern Hemisphere)
Turbidity from runoff reduces visibility and may increase encounter risk

researchPapers.title: Shark behaviour and ecology in response to environmental variation
keyFindings: Temperature drives seasonal migration patterns for multiple shark species
Nearshore movements increase with water temperatures above 20°C
Environmental fluctuations correlate with changes in habitat use

researchPapers.title: Global patterns and predictions of seafloor biomass using random forests
keyFindings: Swell and wave action influence nearshore prey availability
Moderate swell conditions (1.5-3m) associated with increased predator activity in surf zones

researchPapers.title: Coastal urbanization and marine predator-prey dynamics
keyFindings: Rainfall events increase nutrient runoff, affecting coastal prey distribution
Turbidity from storm water discharge may mask visual predator cues
Urban coastal zones show distinct environmental risk patterns

researchPapers.title: Shark movement patterns and environmental drivers in temperate coastal waters
keyFindings: Sharks exhibit predictable responses to temperature gradients
Summer months correlate with increased nearshore presence
Water quality and visibility impact predator foraging efficiency

researchPapers.title: Environmental factors influencing shark bite incidents
keyFindings: Combination of environmental factors better predicts risk than single variables
Rainfall preceding beach activity increases turbidity and reduces water clarity
Seasonal water temperature is the strongest single predictor

dataProvenance.description: Daily rainfall totals from Sydney Observatory Hill (Station 066062) and regional observation stations
Sea surface temperature from Sydney offshore buoys and coastal stations (Fort Denison and Sydney offshore observations)
Significant wave height from offshore observation buoys in the Sydney region
Water quality is estimated as a proxy based on recent rainfall. Heavy rainfall (>45mm in 48h) is assumed to cause runoff and reduced water clarity/increased turbidity.

disclaimer: This system provides an environmental risk assessment based on known correlations between weather/ocean conditions and shark activity patterns from peer-reviewed research. It is NOT a shark detection or sighting system. The risk levels are heuristic estimates and should be used in conjunction with official beach safety information, lifeguard warnings, and personal judgement. Always swim at patrolled beaches, follow local signage, and never swim alone. The Bureau of Meteorology data used is provided 'as-is' and may be subject to delays or outages.

methodology.overview: This system implements a rule-based risk scoring model that evaluates five key environmental conditions associated with increased shark activity in the scientific literature. Each condition is weighted based on its relative importance in published research.

conditions.name: High Water Temperature
conditions.rationale: Multiple studies show shark nearshore activity increases with water temperature, particularly above 20°C in Sydney region

conditions.name: Heavy Rainfall (48h)
conditions.rationale: Significant rainfall causes runoff and turbidity, reducing visibility and potentially increasing encounter risk

conditions.name: Swell Height in Risk Range
conditions.rationale: Moderate swell conditions associated with increased prey activity in surf zones, attracting predators

conditions.name: Summer Season
conditions.rationale: Seasonal patterns show peak shark presence during Southern Hemisphere summer months

conditions.name: Poor Water Quality
conditions.rationale: Reduced visibility from turbidity may increase risk of accidental encounters

methodology.scoring: Each condition contributes its weight to the total score if met. Score ranges map to five risk levels: Low (0-20), Moderate (21-40), High (41-60), Severe (61-80), Catastrophic (81-100). If ALL conditions are met simultaneously, the score is escalated to Catastrophic.
